Description: 'The Florentine Picture-Chronicle' page from the album (verso of 1889,0314.1): the Triumph of Joseph with the Biblical figure seated on a triumphal car with two vases holding ears of corn, the landscape background continuing to right-hand opening 1890,0314.3 Pen and brown ink and brown wash over black chalk and stylus
Curator's comments: Watermark: Gothic R The seven thin and seven fat ears of corn were in the dream of the Pharaoh that Joseph interpreted for him. The Pharaoh's gratitude for Joseph is described in Genesis XL: 39-43 'And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, Forasmuch as God hath shewed thee all this, there is none so discreet and wise as thou art: 40Thou shalt be over my house, and according unto thy word shall all my people be ruled: only in the throne will I be greater than thou. 41And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, See, I have set thee over all the land of Egypt. 42And Pharaoh took off his ring from his hand, and put it upon Joseph's hand, and arrayed him in vestures of fine linen, and put a gold chain about his neck; 43And he made him to ride in the second chariot which he had; and they cried before him, Bow the knee: and he made him ruler over all the land of Egypt'). Lit.: S. Colvin, 'A Florentine Picture Chronicle', London, 1898; A.E. Popham and P. Pouncey, 'Italian drawings in the BM, the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries', London, 1950, I, no. 274, II, pls. CCXXXVII-CCXLI. For a description of the album, see 1889,0527.1 to 95. See also 1890,0314.3 to 4 for folio 14, and 1900,0526.1 to 8 for folios 9, 22, 36 and 47.
Bibliographic references: Popham & Pouncey 1950 / The Fourteenth and Fifteenth Centuries (274)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Ruskin Museum (Trustees of Sheffield)
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: F A C Prestel (Frankfurt)
Acquisition notes: Popham & Pouncey 1950 Please see 1889,0527.1-95 for further provenance
